description: From Middle English thwiten, from Old English þwītan (“to cut, cut off”), from Proto-Germanic *þwītaną (“to split”). See whittle, and compare thwaite (“a piece of land”), doit (“small coin, small amount, bit”).

verbs.description: thwite (third-person singular simple present thwites, present participle thwiting, simple past and past participle thwited)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, UK, dialect) To cut or clip with a knife; to whittle.
